item.title: Pokemon Gen 10 Can't Fall Back into Old Habits With One Recurring Mechanic
item.description:
Highlights

  • Players can ride Legendary Pokemon like Koraidon and Miraidon, offering versatile travel options with evolving abilities.
  • Scarlet and Violet eliminate the need for HMs and HM slaves, enhancing the gameplay experience.
  • The next Pokemon generation should innovate with mountable Legendaries and avoid reverting to older, less dynamic transportation methods.

Pokemon Scarlet and Violet features time travel and the powerful Paradox Pokemon from the past and future. Unlike many prior Pokemon games, players encounter and befriend the Legendary Pokemon early on. This allows players to start forming a bond with the Legendaries quickly.

Most interestingly, the Legendaries can be ridden, making it a breeze to explore Paldea. Gen 10 should not take a step back and return to previous forms of transport, many of which require the use of HMs. Instead, it should take notes from Pokemon Scarlet and Violet and have Pokemon that can transport players anywhere.

Riding Legendary Pokemon in Scarlet and Violet

In Scarlet and Violet , players can ride the Legendary Pokemon Koraidon and Miraidon. The Pokemon are extremely versatile and can ride over water and glide down from heights. At first, the Legendaries can’t do much but as they eat Herba Mystica sandwiches, they gain more abilities. The Pokemon aren’t just for traversing, however, and Koraidon and Miraidon can be used in battle.

Having players ride the Legendary Pokemon was a good move by Game Freak. It gives players the chance to spend time with the Legendary Pokemon, which allows players to bond with them. Furthermore, it eliminates the need for HMs which can be annoying to use, and it eliminates the need for an ‘HM slave,’ which is a relatively weak Pokemon that most HMs are slapped onto. Such a Pokemon is used for getting past obstacles instead of battling.

Transport in Past Pokemon Games

In past Pokemon games, players have been able to get around with various means including rollerblades, bicycles, the Rotom Bike, and Ride Pokemon such as the Tauros from Sun and Moon . These are good ways to get around the different Pokemon regions. However, none of them are as good as riding the Legendaries of Scarlet and Violet .

Why Gen 10 Shouldn’t Fall Back Into Old Habits

The old mounts and transport methods from past games were fun, but they did come with downsides. They couldn’t glide or climb up mountains, which is something Koraidon and Miraidon can do when they’ve fully powered up. Additionally, the old traversal methods required HMs to get past trees and dark caves. This requires wasting a Pokemon’s move slot on an HM that isn’t particularly viable in battle.

The next generation of Pokemon needs to find a way to reuse Scarlet and Violet ’s ability to ride Legendaries, but it has to be done in a smart way that doesn’t feel like a repetition of Gen 9. Going back to old forms of transport would be a bad move, especially after the convenience of Scarlet and Violet ’s mounts.

Scarlet and Violet introduce an interesting way to get around while switching up the formula of how Legendaries are encountered. The next generation should also feature Legendaries that serve as mounts, but it needs to be done uniquely. Returning to old means of transport would feel too stale. The next Pokemon game is Pokemon Legends: Z-A , and players may see how Game Freak is expanding on the ideas present in Scarlet and Violet .

item.title: MultiVersus: How to Unlock Banana Guard and Jason Voorhees
item.description:
With the full launch of MultiVersus , several new characters have been added to the game's exciting roster. While the creators have confirmed that all of the game's characters will be available in the shop, some of the newly featured characters can be unlocked through special events.

Two such new characters are the Banana Guard from Adventure Time and Jason Vorhees from the Friday the 13th franchise, both of which need to be unlocked by completing some easy tasks as of writing this guide.

How to Unlock Banana Guard in MultiVersus

Banana Guard is a newly added Bruiser class character in MultiVersus and one of the game's strongest Bruisers, along with Shaggy, Taz, and Batman.

The Banana Guard can be unlocked in MultiVersus by logging in to the game for two days straight . You do not need to engage in any matches to unlock the character; simply logging in to the game's main screen will contribute towards the login reward. Furthermore, logging in for seven days will earn players the Lady Banana Guard skin variation.

Both the Banana Guard and Lady Banana Guard skins can be claimed from the Training section of the Missions menu once you have logged in for the required number of days.

However, the developers have not specified how long this log-in prize would be accessible for players to claim. Because all of the characters will eventually find their way to the in-game market, you will be able to purchase them using fighter cash in the future.

How to Unlock Jason Voorhees in MultiVersus

Jason Voorhees, who appears on Friday the 13th, is another formidable character introduced to MultiVersus' ever-expanding roster in Season 1.

As of the writing of this guide, Jason Voorhees can only be unlocked with Season 1's premium battle pass . The Premium Battle Pass costs 950 Gleamium; thus, gamers must purchase this character with real money. However, Jason Voorhees is available as a Tier 1 battle pass prize; therefore, there is not much effort necessary to get this character.

Players who participated in MultiVersus' Open Beta will be able to obtain the characters for free as a prize, as the premium components of the Season 1 Battle Pass are free for them due to their beta testing involvement.

However, gamers who did not participate in the open beta or purchased the Premium Battle Pass will have to wait until Season 2 to access this character. Jason Voorhees is likely to become available in the in-game market with the Season 2 update since every character will ultimately be able to be unlocked with fighter currency.

item.title: V Rising PS5 Review
item.description:
V Rising began its journey back in 2022 as an early access game exclusive to PC. Even then, it quickly grew to prominence among survival game enthusiasts, who praised the game for its deep customization, engaging combat, and unique, vampiric premise. Now that V Rising has come to PS5, console players can dive into the game's strengths and weaknesses for themselves.

There aren't many survival games built around a vampire player-character, but V Rising aims to be the definitive title in that niche. It takes place in Vardoran, a land ravaged by an ancient vampire civil war and reeling from the tyranny of Dracula himself, a power-hungry vampire craving total submission from both vampires and humans. Players assume the role of a custom vampire, awakened from a deep slumber and ready to pursue their destiny as an independent champion of their own domain.

But V Rising is rather sparse when it comes to plot. The closest thing to a main campaign is the player's pursuit and defeat of V Bloods, distinct bosses scattered throughout Vardoran. These V Bloods, highly varied and well-designed, sit at the heart of V Rising 's gameplay loop—and it's quite a satisfying loop indeed.

V Rising Is a Delightful Cocktail of Combat and Customization

At first glance, V Rising doesn't seem too removed from familiar survival gameplay systems: players farm materials for use as construction components, both for their gear and for their home base. But V Rising makes a few clever, thematically appropriate departures from its contemporaries.

For one thing, the castle-building system, on top of being intuitive, offers concrete gameplay advantages in addition to the expected sense of self-expression. Since players will take damage from sun exposure, there is a mechanical benefit to building a complete structure, as roofs provide shelter from the sun's rays. Vaulted ceilings will automatically appear once players have enclosed a room with castle walls, making the construction process feel even more natural. With these systems, it's remarkably easy to craft aesthetically pleasing, practical bases in the game.

One particularly interesting mechanic is the blood purity/type system, which gives players different buffs based on which NPC they drain of blood. This makes blood-sucking an engaging, useful tool, rather than a chore designed to top-off an obligatory resource.

There's a pervasive sense of synergy in V Rising 's crafting mechanics. Players will quickly gain access to different options for refining materials, allowing for the creation of more powerful gear, which in turn makes both combat and resource-farming more efficient and fruitful. As one's castle grows in both size and utility, it's hard not to personalize thanks to the surprisingly vast collection of craftable cosmetics, which is constantly being expanded with the defeat of new V Bloods and the discovery of randomized blueprint drops in the game world. Fighting V Bloods and seeking out building materials is all the more satisfying thanks to the game's combat, which hits far above the survival genre weight class.

V Rising 's combat is similar to other action-RPGs like Diablo , but with enough differences that keep it from feeling derivative. Players gain access to basic weapons like swords, axes, and spears early on, but the combat sandbox slowly opens up with the arrival of armaments like crossbows, pistols, and whips. There's also a laundry list of different spells and special abilities across six distinct magic categories:

  • Blood
  • Chaos
  • Unholy
  • Illusion
  • Frost
  • Storm

With the vast majority of V Blood bosses rewarding skill points in these categories, players will quickly amass a wide assortment of unique abilities, including variations on staple moves like dashing and countering. Though the game has a lot in common with action-RPGs, it has virtually nothing resembling strict builds or rigid stat assignments, making it painless and rewarding to experiment with different ability combinations. This flexibility and the rapid pace of new spell unlocks keep V Rising 's combat from ever getting dull or repetitive.

New spells arrive at a steady cadence, but the same can't be said for gear, which forms the brunt of V Rising 's linear power creep. V Rising determines power by an overall gear score, meaning that no matter how many enemies a player defeats, they won't grow stronger without higher-level weapons and armor. It can take a while to unlock more powerful gear, and then this gear must be crafted with resources that are increasingly difficult to obtain. Defeating V Blood enemies is the most effective way to get new gear, especially early on, but it's not easy to overcome a V Blood when you're underleveled, which can result in a feeling of painfully slow progression, especially when playing solo.

V Rising 's steady grind is aided by its exciting combat and exploration, but its pacing issues may intimidate or bore newcomers to the survival RPG genre. Likewise, if a player has a particularly low tolerance for grind-heavy gameplay, V Rising 's progression has the potential to lead to some dull moments. Progression can speed up a bit once players unlock the Study, which facilitates faster research of item blueprints, but the game can still hit some slow patches occasionally, especially during the mid-game, as RNG becomes a more important factor in blueprint acquisition.

V Rising Plays Great On PS5, with Some Minor Growing Pains

V Rising 's transition to PlayStation is about as smooth as one could ask for. The port runs well, and I experienced only the most negligible framerate stutters and graphical glitches during my playthrough. Online performance was strong for me as well, with no major hiccups on even the most packed servers. Overall, the game looks and performs about as strongly on PS5 as it would on a PC running at max settings.

It isn't without its hiccups, though, the most significant being controller support. The game was built for a keyboard-and-mouse setup, and while the DualSense is serviceable, it can feel a bit clumsy at times. Aiming spells and projectiles with the right stick can be finicky and unreliable, especially without any aim assist or a lock-on feature. Similarly, the button-mapping for special weapon attacks is a little awkward compared to the regular key-bindings on PC, and it's easy to select the wrong option from the radial menu, especially in the heat of combat - something that can be particularly frustrating since the healing ability is accessed through said menu.

Additionally, V Rising 's base building doesn't feel nearly as good with a controller, as placing objects with the analog stick is sometimes cumbersome and imprecise. Inventory management with a controller is also a bit slow, but not egregiously so. In general, controller support just doesn't feel like a top priority.

While the above issues are notable, they are by no means dealbreakers. After a few hours, most players will learn the ropes of V Rising 's combat, and the DualSense controls won't feel like much of a hindrance. Still, some button remapping options or a lock-on system might have made controller gameplay feel a bit more natural.

Minor issues of pacing and controls aside, V Rising on PS5 is a more than worthy port. Its expressive customization options, unfolding combat mechanics, and flexible build options have made it a must-own for PC players, and now the same can be said for PlayStation players. If you're a fan of survival games, action-RPGs, and Gothic horror, you can't do much better than V Rising .

V Rising releases June 11, 2024 for PS5, and the PC version is available now. Game Rant was provided a PS5 code for this review.

item.title: Final Fantasy 7 Rebirth's Cutest Side Quest Can't Be a One-Off
item.description:
Well-designed side quests are often hard to come by; developers sometimes want to add more content to a game without distracting players from the main story too much, but this usually means side quests have unfulfilling objectives. For the most part, side quests such as these amount to little more than "fetch and kill" quests, which, as their moniker suggests, see players either fetching an item for the quest-giver or killing an enemy. Final Fantasy 7 Rebirth is one of the latest games to include plenty of side quests for players to complete, and many of them happen to fall on the better side of quest design. In fact, it's possible for players to miss out on some decent character development and worldbuilding should they skip some of Final Fantasy 7 Rebirth 's side quests.

While many of the side quests offered in Final Fantasy 7 Rebirth are more than worth doing, there is one, in particular, that is highly distinct from the others. "When Words Won't Do" is an optional quest that players can pick up once they arrive in Under Junon, and it just so happens to be what is arguably Final Fantasy 7 Rebirth 's cutest side quest. Its value goes far beyond its cute factor, however, as its design, execution, and even its music all make for a unique experience in the game that other side quests don't provide. As such, perhaps Part 3 of the Final Fantasy 7 Remake trilogy should consider bringing this quest (and its main character) back for an encore.

"When Words Won't Do" Needs an Encore in Final Fantasy 7 Remake Part 3

"When Words Won't Do" Features an Adorable Dog and Has Its Own Music Track

Final Fantasy 7 Rebirth 's side quests aren't necessarily all the same, but almost none of them stand out like "When Words Won't Do." Not long after they arrive in Under Junon, players can speak to the Under Junon Sheriff, Rhonda, to receive the quest. She then proceeds to task players with escorting Salmon the porter dog as he delivers money to her estranged son. She hasn't seen him since he left town without looking back, and she now wants to send him some Gil as a way of letting him be a “grown man” and live his own life.

Once players meet up with Salmon, a fun electronic music track begins playing to show the quest's main journey has begun. Most of this part of the quest involves nothing more than following Salmon as he braves the wilds of Junon with his newfound friends behind him, but players are also required to overcome multiple enemy encounters along the way. Interestingly, the battle music during this quest has also been exchanged for something electronic that is more akin to the main theme that plays while following Salmon. All of this doesn't necessarily make for an exciting set of objectives, but its uniqueness comes from its adorable animal companion and the upbeat music that plays throughout the quest.

Final Fantasy 7 Remake Part 3 Needs to Bring Back Salmon the Dog

It would be a shame to let such a cute side quest be a one-off after Final Fantasy 7 Rebirth , especially after introducing players to Salmon and even giving him his own theme song. As such, Final Fantasy 7 Rebirth 's sequel should see Salmon return for another quest or two. It might be too much to ask to make Salmon a permanent companion, but Part 3 of the Final Fantasy 7 Remake trilogy could still amp up any potential quests associated with him. In any case, it would be nice to see him again in the next game. If not Salmon, then maybe another dog or animal companion with its own theme song could take his place.

item.title: Stardew Valley: 13 Mods That Add Marriage Candidates
item.description:
Highlights

  • Stardew Valley has a passionate fanbase that creates mods adding new marriage candidates, like polyamorous relationships and unique NPCs.
  • The game's 1.6 update added new content but mods like Romanceable Rasmodius & Romanceable Rasmodia bring fresh romance options to players.
  • Mods like Ridgeside Village can offer a wealth of new marriage candidates, adding excitement and replay value for players looking for love.

Stardew Valley is a beloved indie farming RPG that simulates a peaceful life in the idyllic Pelican Town. After taking over their grandfather's farm, players can grow, charm and quest their way through the game to unlock achievements, secrets and to have an all around wonderful life. Since its release in 2016, the game has gained a passionate and loyal fanbase which has supported developer ConcernedApe at every turn.

To further show their affection for Stardew Valley , many fans of the game have created extensive, well-developed mods that allow players to explore the game even further. Mods are typically downloadable content that allows fans to adjust games to include certain aspects that the original game does not have, such as new farming equipment or easy teleportation. Some mods are built exclusively to facilitate the mechanics of the game, while others introduce entirely new areas or NPCs to Stardew Valley. There's a multitude of unique mods that show immense dedication and care, including some that broaden the dating pool for players that are looking for love.

Updated June 11th, 2024, by Alexandra O'Leary: After Stardew Valley's highly anticipated 1.6 update, a whole wave of players have returned to the game with a renewed passion. The 1.6 update added a great selection of new content to keep players interested, and served as a great way to distract gamers while they wait for ConcernedApe's next game, Haunted Chocolatier. For those who've already made their way through all the new features of this update, mods are an excellent way to keep the game fresh and fun. Mods can impact all aspects of a game, and there's a particularly good selection for those who want to expand the dating roster. New romanceable NPCs add even more challenge and dimension to the game, and for those who want a little more love in their lives, there's a whole world of single people just waiting to fall for Pelican Town's newest farmer. With that in mind, some more mods that add romanceable characters to Stardew Valley have been added to this list in its latest update.

13 Polyamory Sweet

0 Additional Marriage Candidates

  • Via: Polyamory Sweet

The Polyamory Sweet mod is a little unlike the others that add additional or new marriage candidates. Instead, this mod introduces the concepts of polyamory and consensual non-monogamy to Pelican Town and allows players to have multiple partners at a time. So, while it doesn't exactly add partners, it opens up the dating pool substantially.

For functional reasons, the player will likely have one main spouse (which can be changed freely), but other than that, they can have multiple partners and spouses, which will bring unique rooms to the house. It also allows the player's other spouses to attend new weddings, other NPCs to kiss, and lets multiple characters sleep in one bed. This mod is all about free love, and gives players the chance to get to know all the people in Pelican Town on another level. It even adds a new NPC (non-romanceable) to oversee the custom items that help players manage their life, and the mod is regularly updated by its creator.

12 Shiko

1 Additional Marriage Candidate

  • Via: Shiko

There are plenty of custom NPCs in the world of Stardew Valley mods, and gamers all over the world work hard to tailor the game in a personal way. Shiko is a great example of the kinds of NPCs that fans are making, and is a great way to see how much they can add to the Stardew experience.

Shiko is a cool ex-model who moves to Pelican Town for a little peace after her life of stardom. This effortlessly-stylish icon comes with her own set of heart events and is completely romanceable, meaning players can marry her and have her move out of the Stardrop Saloon and into the farmer's house. Any player who wants a mysterious and glamorous partner will absolutely love this mod.

11 Isla

1 Additional Marriage Candidate

  • Via: Isla

Isla is another custom NPC mod, adding a mysterious new character who's a little harder to pin down than the usual Pelican Town singles. Isla is an aqua-haired NPC with a mystical nature whom the player can meet if they venture to the beach at the right time. Getting to know her will reveal brilliant secrets, and slowly, the player can grow a beautiful relationship with her.

Isla is a very cool and unique custom NPC unlike any other denizen of Stardew Valley , which gives players a really fresh romantic experience. She prefers sea-based gifts and comes complete with all the heart events, as well as her own spousal room if players decide to marry her. She even has different seasonal outfits, just like Stardew Valley's 1.6 update, and attends Pelican Town's various events - with her own dialogue and location.

10 Romanceable Rasmodius And Romanceable Rasmodia

1 Additional Marriage Candidate

  • Via: Romanceable Rasmodius & Romanceable Rasmodia

This mod does add a "new" marriage candidate, but not quite in the way players may think. Romanceable Rasmodius specifically makes Rasmodius a marriage candidate and brings 6 unique heart events as players grow their relationship with him. It also adds dozens of new dialogue lines for Rasmodius and adjusts his behaviour post-marriage. The mod works alongside Stardew Valley Expanded , and will need that installed to work properly.

Romanceable Rasmodia works with Stardew Valley Expanded or Romaceable Rasmodius to make a female iteration of Rasmodius that is romanceable. It literally turns Rasmodius into Rasmodia, and will adjust the game to fit Rasmodia's character without changing too much else. It's a perfect option for players who don't really want to switch up their game, but would like to see a cool Witch in the forest tower instead of a Wizard.

9 Always Raining In The Valley

1 Additional Marriage Candidate

  • Via: Always Raining in the Valley

This brilliant Stardew Valley mod adds three wonderful new NPCs, and one of them - Sterling - is available for players to fall in love with. It's a mod that specifically builds on the East Scarp mod, so players should be sure to download that one first. All three new characters, Henry, Mia, and Sterling Cooper, have unique dialogue and outfits that change based on the event and location.

The main draw of this mod is the new storyline it adds to the East Scarp area, but Sterling is a great new addition to the marriage pool. Although he's a little bit lost, his genuine nature makes him a very endearing and a brilliant new choice for players - particularly since he's unlike any other marriage candidate so far. The mod also adds new recipes for any players who enjoy cooking. It's worth noting that the mod does not change the weather, and the title is more for dramatic impact.

8 Adventurer's Guild Expanded

2 Additional Marriage Candidates

  • Via: Adventurer's Guild Expanded

The Adventurer's Guild Expanded mod elaborates on the monster aspects of Stardew Valley and adds completely new lore on where they come from, as well as additional information about the mines. Players can even become friends with a little monster companion who will come to live in their house.

Most importantly, this mod adds two additional NPCs - Marlon's children - who move to Pelican Town to start a monster research wing of the Adventurer's Guild. Gabriel and Zinnia move to the Stardew Valley as young adults, and each of them have 6 unique events at different stages of their relationship with the player. This mod adds a whole new dimension to the mines/monster sections of the game, and both new NPCs bring something fresh to the dating pool while also giving the player a little more insight into Marlon's backstory.

7 Boarding House And Bus Stop Extension

2 Additional Marriage Candidates

  • Via: Boarding House and Bus Stop Extension Mod

This Stardew Valley mod adds a boarding house behind the bus stop, along with a few new characters and dateable NPCs. The great part about the Boarding House and Bus Stop Extension mod is that it provides a home for any players who want to create and add their own custom NPCs without having to design a whole new area or house for them to live in.

Any players simply looking to jump in and date a new NPC will be happy to meet Greg , who can be found at the end of the new abandoned mine. Greg has six events that are generally mine and artifact oriented, making him perfect for players that are eager to explore the mines. Players can also romance Sheila, the daughter of Joe (who runs the boarding house) and owner of the brand new Buffalo Ranch.

6 Lunna - Astray In Stardew Valley

3 Additional Marriage Candidates

  • Via: Lunna - Astray in Stardew Valley Mod

This charming mod focuses on the story of Lunna , a mysterious woman who is not quite what she seems. Lunna will be under the care of Rasmodius, the reclusive wizard found in Cindersnap Forest. Lunna: Astray in Stardew Valley adds three brand new dateable NPCs: Lunna, Bianka and Raphael.

Players will have to play through Lunna's story in order to meet Bianka and Raphael, but once they do, all three characters are romance options and players can marry any one of them. There are also exclusive recipes that can be unlocked for any Stardew Valley cooking enthusiasts. This mod adds an extra spark of magic and exploration, allowing players to visit Lunna's home, Umuwi, if they're persistent enough with her story.

5 Downtown Zuzu

6 Additional Marriage Candidates

  • Via: Downtown Zuzu Mod

Downtown Zuzu is a cool, expansive mod that adds an entirely new area to Stardew Valley. Downtown Zuzu is more urban than Pelican Town, and offers a huge amount of new places to explore and characters to meet. Some of the best places in this mod include a busy mall, a lovely high street and an airport.

Regarding romance, Downtown Zuzu adds 6 brand-new dateable NPCs. Each of them are unique and interesting in their own right, ranging from shy goth-girl Gwen to uppity Joja CEO Kristoff . This mod adds an entirely new dimension to the game and the dateable characters are very much integrated into the complex new areas of Stardew Valley.

4 Stardew Valley Expanded

6 Additional Marriage Candidates

  • Via: Stardew Valley Expanded Mod

Longtime fans of Stardew Valley will likely be familiar with the Stardew Valley Expanded mod . It is a massive mod that adds absolutely everything to the game, expanding on the world, NPCs and even the types of fish players can catch. The amount of care and dedication put into this mod cannot be overstated.

Along with the incredible amount of content players get from it, Stardew Valley Expanded also adds 6 new dateable characters. The familiar face of the Wizard is among these, which will delight any players who have been keen to romance Rasmodius . However, there are 5 other brand-new characters with carefully created backstories and dialogue, such as daring adventurer Lance or classy mother Olivia .

3 Looking For Love

9 Additional Marriage Candidates

  • Via: Looking for Love Mod

Looking for Love is a great mod that allows players to romance some of the other single, but previously unavailable NPCs. Some Stardew Valley players, particularly older ones, can be disappointed that most of the bachelor/bachelorette NPCs are young adults. There are many players who wish to romance some of the more mature and endearing singles in Pelican Town.

This mod will allow players to date the likes of Gus, Clint, Marnie and Pam . In total, it adds 9 of the unmarried, classic Stardew Valley NPCs to the dating pool which offers players new dialogue, events and spouse rooms. It is worth noting that this mod specifically builds on another mod named Siv's Marriage Mod which, unfortunately, has not been updated since 2017. Looking For Love offers updated files and relevant fixes, and is more reliable for players who are looking to dive into this new pool of dateable characters.

2 East Scarp

10 Additional Marriage Candidates

  • Via: East Scarp Mod

Alongside Stardew Valley Expanded and Downtown Zuzu, the East Scarp mod adds an entirely new area of Stardew Valley for players to explore. It includes new homes, shops and secrets to uncover, as well as a group of 10 new dateable NPCs. This allows players to experience new romance events, areas and a brand-new bird-watching aspect.

These dateable NPC's cover a broad spectrum, including Sen , a mine-dwelling shadow, and Aideen a well-spoken, Victorian-era enthusiast. These new marriage candidates also tie in with familiar Stardew Valley faces, such as Tristan , a rebellious but charming adventurer, who is (non-canonically) Jas' father.

1 Ridgeside Village

22 Additional Marriage Candidates

  • Via: Ridgeside Village Mod

Ridgeside Village is another enormous mod for Stardew Valley, adding an entirely new village along with an incredible slew of over 50 NPCs. Longtime fans of the game will be satisfied for months while playing through all the new content, including a vast field of dateable characters. This also makes it perfect for replays, allowing gamers to choose different partners and options each time.

Ridgeside Village offers 22 new marriage candidates, some of them obvious bachelors and bachelorettes, and others more difficult to romance. Among the bachelors are June , a gentle pianist, and Ian , a kindhearted and reliable laborer. A few of the bachelorettes include Alissa , another farmer with a flair for the arts, and the awkwardly adorable Flor . For players after the trickier dateable NPCs, there are a few secrets to winning their hearts. For example, Irene and Anton can be marriage candidates, but players will have to dedicate time to reaching their 8 heart events in order to pursue them. Others, like Daia and Jio , are unlocked after certain events and stories are completed.
